Article/0-0-0-18/static-site-generation.html:
Use Nullstack to generate static websites for lightning-fast static applications using the full power of the Nullstack client without the need for a node.js back-end.<\/p>

Static sites are useful for read-only applications like blogs and documentation.<\/p>

ðŸ’¡ This documentation is actually a static site generated with Nullstack.<\/p> <\/blockquote>

All the benefits of server-side rendering<\/a> apply to static generated sites.<\/p>

You can generate a static website from your Nullstack application with the following npx<\/code> command:<\/p> 

npx nullstack build --<\/span>mode=<\/span>ssg --<\/span>output=<\/span>ssg
<\/code><\/pre>



ðŸ”¥ You must be in a Nullstack project folder to run this command.<\/p>
<\/blockquote>

By default, it will create your static application in the ssg<\/strong> folder you can override this with the --output<\/code> flag.<\/p>

The builder will run your application in production mode and crawl every href<\/code> attribute it finds in your DOM.<\/p>

The manifest.json<\/a> and the contents of the public folder will be copied into the target folder.<\/p>

Besides generating raw HTML it will also generate a JSON file for each route with a copy of the state.<\/p>

On the first visit to your static application, HTML will be served and hydrated.<\/p>

On the subsequent requests, Nullstack will fetch the generated JSON and update the application state without ever reloading the page.<\/p>

This, in fact, gives you not only a static generated site, but a static generated API with the calculated state that feeds a Single Page Application with zero costs.<\/p>

Good Pratices<\/a><\/h2>
You can add a script to your package.json<\/strong> to generate your static website in a custom folder:<\/p>

{<\/span>
  "name"<\/span>:<\/span> "nullstack.github.io"<\/span>,<\/span>
  "scripts"<\/span>:<\/span> {<\/span>
    "start"<\/span>:<\/span> "npx nullstack start"<\/span>,<\/span>
    "build"<\/span>:<\/span> "npx nullstack build --mode=ssg --output=docs"<\/span>,<\/span>
  }<\/span>
  
  ...<\/span>
}<\/span>

<\/code><\/pre>

Caveats<\/a><\/h2>
Before generating the HTML, Nullstack will wait for prepare<\/code><\/a> and initiate<\/code><\/a> of all components of that route to be resolved.<\/p>

You can mix modes and request further server functions by pointing worker.api<\/code> and hosting the server bundle in a node.js environment.<\/p>

Nullstatic will crawl a "/404" URL and generate both a "/404.html" and a "/404/index.html".<\/p>
